Put your hands down, and then you realize you're just in front of a sandwich shop on Portrero Hill. I don't know which of the two women in the shop is Hazel, but it's a charmer of a place. They apparently serve breakfast bagels, but my friend and I came by over the weekend for one of their seven sandwiches. Except for the $4.75 PB&J (which I must try), all of them range from $6.50 to $6.75.

They also have three tempting salads, all freshly made - pasta, Greek and a corn-bean combo - which sell for $2.95 for a half-pint serving. The best deal is definitely the half-sandwich/half-salad for $6.75 especially since the sandwiches are pretty hefty. I had the roast beef and cheddar, and while the meat is sparse between the sourdough slices, it is chockfull of lettuce, tomato and other healthy goodies. I like the use of the Chinese take-out container for the salad, though I was hoping for a Kosher pickle to complete the picture. There are only two tables, each with two chairs, outside on the sidewalk and a bench, so be prepared to take it to go. Farley's is just a couple of doors down, and an iced latte would be a nice way to wash it all down. This one is definitely a cut above the neighborhood sandwich shop.

FOOD - 4 stars...fresh ingredients elevate this place 
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...well, the outdoor table is nice on a sunny day...close your eyes and it's the Hamptons
SERVICE - 3.5 stars
OVERALL - 4 stars...sandwich shops are a dime a dozen, but a good one is worth going a few more blocks
author: Ed U.

description: A good place to pickup a sandwich on a way to a picnic since Hazel's is close to 18th Street exit off of I280 Freeway.  Probably a 5 Star shop for Petrero Hill residents, but 3 stars for me since I live in SOMA.  One of the awards displayed on the wall is "Best Place to Meet Locals," which explains how this place is loved by nearby residents.  Sandwich was made on fresh bread and ripe tomatoes.  I wished they would pile on a little bit more meat, but overall a solid sandwich.  Use this place as a takeout place, because they only have several seats outside.
author: トモ T.

description: I am unabashedly a carnivore.  This is a testament to how yummy the tofu breakfast burritos are at Hazel's.  At 6.95 it's a wee bit pricey, but absolutely delicious.  I keep meaning to revert to my meat eatin' ways, but can't bear to not order the tofu...  I've also had the oatmeal and it's also fantastic.
author: Helen F.

description: Delicious sandwiches (big enough to eat half and put half away). Friendly service. No place to sit.
author: Chelsea F.

description:
The turkey with cranberry sauce sandwich blew my tastebuds away! They have such fresh sandwiches and such funky combos, it's like getting a sandwich made from your crazy aunt Hazel.
Only drawback is no seating, so prepare to bunker down at a park to devour their yumminess!
author: Brittany T.

description: Been 10 years almost since I visited last.  The turkey cranberry smoked provolone is still as good.  It's the perfect little working take out sandwich place.  I love it and always will.  Seems like new owners but the food and quality is the same!  They take cards now which makes it more convenient.
author: Mark M.

description: Very good sandwiches and pretty good lunch burritos.  I had the steak melt on a dutch crunch, which was pretty fantastic, and the grilled chicken + grilled veggie burrito, which was okay.  Not much seating, so either take the sandwich for a walk or sit down next door at Farley's.
author: Max L.

description: Yay!  I love this place.  I often to go Farley's for coffee, then go to Hazel's and grab one of their AWESOME breakfast burritos.  That whole area of 18th street is so homey and comfortable.  Hazel's is a little hidden gem.
author: Steve S.

description:
Best sandwiches in Potrero Hill. Period. 

I've been frequent this neighborhood joint for years now and they always deliver. The ingredients are fresh and there's something in the dutch crutch bread that is addictive. Mmmmmm.

Anyways, I've only tried the sandwiches because there are so many and so good that I see no reason to stray to the other menu options. 

I'm so happy that Hazel's Kitchen is so close.
author: Juan V.

description:
Perhaps my enthusiasm for the sandwich I had yesterday at Hazel's Kitchen was due to my extreme hunger. But no, on second thought, it was just damn good.

The John's Special sandwich features turkey, bacon, provolone, pesto, veggies, and Hazel's dressing on your choice of bread. I chose the whole wheat--and I'm glad I did because those two slices were huge! At first I thought there was no way I'd finish even half of the sandwich, because it was stacked about three inches high with generous amounts of everything. I had to stop myself at 3/4 of the sandwich before I exploded. Oh, and I'm guessing the Hazel's dressing is some type of magical vinaigrette, because I devoured everything, including the tomatoes and cucumbers, which I'd usually toss.

I also had a bite of sandwich 3b: rare roast beef with horseradish sauce. That was good, but I liked mine better. I especially loved that the sandwich was slathered with a horseradish sauce that imparted great flavor but wasn't unbearably hot.

Next time I'm in this cute little neighborhood around lunch time, I'm pretty sure I'll make it back here, especially since Baked is just down the street. If nothing sweet catches your eye at Hazel's, place your order, then mosey down to Baked while you wait for your lunch to be ready.
author: Julie K.

description: Hazel's, oh god where do I start... The best worst sandwich place ever. They are the best sandwich in Potrero Hill, but only because they are the only sandwich place in Potrero Hill. The customer service is the worst, EVER. I was the Duke of this place for over a year while I was living on 20th and out of my 30+ visits they only got my sandwich order right once or twice. Yes that's correct, once or twice. Complete incompetent assholes as am I for continually coming here as many times as I did. The cashier's have a 2nd, maybe 3rd grade education and the attention span of a 13 year old boy. It is sad because they have the potential be so good. Good bread, good ingredients, great location, great menu. My advice? Pull your head out of your ass Hazel and hire some decent people that care about your customers and can stay awake long enough to make a sandwich correctly.
author: Phillip K.

description: If you want really yummy food to go (no seating), this is the place.  In general, I don't like sandwiches (unless I dress it up like an Italian sub with foccasia bread). But they have really good sandwiches here. My fave? Anything on their daily special menu especially their tofu sandwich on a seeded roll! I'm no Vegan either! I usually get 1/2 sandwich 1/2 salad for $8.50 and bring it next door to Farley's cafe where I can eat at a real table! Also, you can shorten your wait if you order by phone first!
author: Caitlyn K.

description:
Typically, I'm good for two meals a day at Hazel's Kitchen and if they were open for dinner I would come close to paying the rent.  Everything that has been said about the sandwiches is true, but the breakfast burritos, bagel egg Sammie's and tacos are high on my list.

I start my mornings brushing up on my Spanish with Alma and Juan always good for a laugh. I have become a fan #5 the vegetarian on a seeded bun. Hold the bacon Amy.

The 18th Street trail is order breakfast at Hazel's Kitchen, coffee at Farley's and then some thing sweet from Baked. A buen dia.
author: Steve A.

description:
Had to wait for guy to get off his cell phone before taking my order.
I ordered a waffle with strawberries.
They charged me for waffle with avocado (3dollars more).
Took extremely long time to make.
Waffle was under cooked, gooey, disgusting.
Brought it back, cashier was unbelieveably rude.
Made no attempt at any point to maintain a friendly, welcoming environment to customers. :(
Never going back.
author: Astro S.

description: Awesome breakfast burrito! I would definitely recommend the chorizo and I am looking forward to coming back for more.
author: Delaney L.

description: I was staying with a friend who lived about five minutes from here, so on her recommendation I decided to grab lunch from this place. The prices are actually really good for the amount of food you get; these sandwiches are HUGE. I think they serve it on mutant bread. Half of these sandwiches is about the size of a normal sandwich you'd get at Starbucks or something like that. I got the cranberry/turkey sandwich and had them put in avocado and bacon for extra. It was amazing. I thought I would save half for later since it really is a two-meal sandwich but I ended up eating the whole thing. Just be prepared to get messy when you try to bite into these things!
author: Sabrina M.

description: You can get good sandwiches in this tiny deli.
author: Erich V.

description:
I love this cute little restaurant.  Bought a sandwich there last week that was one of the best I've ever had.  Tri tip on toasted wheat with vegetable marinated in balsamic vinegar.  Yum!    And it is next door to my favorite coffee shop in SF (Farley's), and you can eat your food from Hazel's at Farley's.  

While you're in the area, also check out Collage, a few doors down.  It is a cute little shop with some vintage pieces and jewelry and soaps and lotions.
author: Cynthia L.

description:
Pretty hit or miss lunch and quick breakfast spot, but overall more hits than misses. The sandwiches are the mainstay of this place.  I've had the pastrami, the John's Special, and the tofu with sauteed vegetables: all were heaping with ingredients (a little sloppy but truly a bang for your buck, especially if you order the half sandwich for 5.25). These are all daily specials, and to mimic what an earlier reviewer said, you can't go wrong with them. The other day I ordered a sandwich from the regular menu and it was a disaster..I ordered the BLTA and there were all of 3 pieces of bacon in the entire sandwich. A very sad thing to behold.


Their soups are so-so; Ive only had the vegetarian chili and was not that impressed.
Their salads are actually quite good; I've had the chicken Caesar (the dressing was good but maybe overly garlicky in my opinion) and a few others..but I don't order them nearly as much as I had in the past since they remodeled last year (now the salads are not really displayed well, so they never catch my eye anymore).

As for breakfast...their oatmeal is by far the best deal, and probably best tasting thing I've had for breakfast there. Their bagels are only okay and compared to the cafe by my house, they are overpriced...This morning I ordered the granola, fresh fruit and yogurt for the first time. I guess it was a mistake. I mean, who puts honeydew and watermelon with their morning yogurt??? Those watery fruits don't really go well with dairy or grains in my opinion. There were a few strawberries, but they should have included bananas and other berries, in my humble opinion.

I've never tried the pancakes, waffles, or the breakfast burrito, so I cannot speak to those items.

A word about beverages: THEY DON'T HAVE COFFEE! They should. Farley's coffee tastes like caca. Hazel's serves pellegrino juices and Juice Squeeze, but I sincerely believe that the best thing on the menu is their Watermelon Aqua Fresca. It's not always advertised/on the menu, but when they have it, you would be doing yourself an unforgettable favor by ordering one. Really, really refreshing and delicious.

Contrary to what I've read here, I think the service is consistent, fast, hardworking and very sweet. The new woman who works there has botched up my order before, but I think she is getting better. I really  have no problem with the service; I don't know what the 1-star reviewer was talking about.
author: Reena R.

description: Love this spot, cheap and good food - and fast!  what else could you ask for?  no seating, but who cares!
author: Adam S.

description: Cute place. Super fresh sandwiches...and by that I mean literally fresh and delicious. Sit outside. It's sunny in Potrero! Or take your food next door to Farley's, but don't be rude, order and enjoy a cup of coffee with it while you're there!
author: L P.

description:
If I could eat Hazel's everyday, I would. This place has such great sandwiches and side dishes. I am a huge fan of the turkey pesto, or the turkey and cranberry, with a side of fruit salad. Yum.

Also to die for? Their pesto lasagna, wish I could make it the way they do, it's sooo good. And the employees are great, quick, friendly and clean. What more could you want?
author: Liz S.

description: Skip Plow and eat here instead. The food is better, the servings more meaningful, the wait is shorter (by hours), and it's less expensive.
author: Jake H.

description:
Ive been here quite a few times the ingredients they use are always really fresh and taste great the downside for me is that evrytime I come here they never get my order right. If I say no cucumber their it is after I get back to work and go to eat it. If i say may mustard and pesto I get back and only find mustard.

Gave Hazels 3 starts because I do like this little place but they need to pay attention to customer orders.
author: Michael W.

description:
This is more of a "grab something and take it home place" for me, but I think the sandwiches are great. They do have a few tables outside and I see that you can sit down next door as well, but I have never stayed to eat.

 I recently tried the Rare Roast Beef with Horseradish Mayo and it was SO good!  I kept thinking about how much I enjoyed it all afternoon.  The tuna and BLT are pretty good, too.

The sandwiches are very large and loaded with ingredients.  I have yet to try the breakfast burritos, but am looking forward to it.
author: Mack S.

description: I live around the corner from Hazels and go here often. Good food and service.
author: Heather B.

description: Awesome Grilled Melt sandwiches, especially the Chicken.  You can taste all the flavors; the key is their homemade dressing.  Great Chilli also.
author: Ken L.

description: Delicious Jumbo artist sandwiches of all sorts! For the price and quality...this place is amazing! I love the Chicken and Beef Sandwiches. Yum! Thank you Hazel's Kitchen for providing great jumbo sandwiches at a reasonable price. I will be back!
author: Cat K.

description: Awesome bagels!!! And of course cream cheese. Yum :)
author: Julie P.

description: Most bomb dot com breakfast burrito I've ever had!
author: Sonal S.

description:
I am highly addicted to their dill salmon spread on a whole wheat bagel with sliced tomato.  Unlike Noah's or Katz's or any other bagel place in the bay area where you have to remind your tripped out server to please cut your bagel down the middle too, Hazel's always gets this right, and makes the cut, after it's been wrapped in tissue paper so you end up with two delectably edible halves.  If I am lucky they haven't run out of bagels and I can still get one past noon.  

I don't think their sandwiches are anything too special, or mind-blowing.  Except that their turkey tastes like real turkey and the roast beef tastes like real roast beef, which is saying a lot.  So kudos to Hazel for fresh ingredients.

I do like the small shop feel of the place. Ok, truth be told, it's tiny!  But it has a quaint new england town feel to it.  Mainly from the decor and the red and white paperware that makes me nostalgic for a good lobster roll.  And the staff are always friendly.  

I'm tempted to give them an extra star for their location adjoining Farley's next door ~ sustenance and your caffeine in one spot!  But it's just a solid good.  Down with grade inflation!
author: Nikki F.

description:
Great sandwich and soup place in Potrero Hill.  

The tomato cabbage soup was AMAZING. And my grilled chicken sandwich on toasted dark rye was very tasty.

What I like most about Hazel's is the location.  It's a great neighborhood soup and sandwich place in Potrero Hill with outdoor chairs and tables.  And it sits next to Farley's.  You can have a great tasting sandwich and great tasting coffee in one stop.
author: Jun B.

description:
3 Stars  Great Sandwiches!

-2 Stars 
 Beyond annoyed and frustrated with the $10 limit on using debit/credit cards to make a purchase!!!
All the sandwiches are under $10, most are $7.50, so you are forced to buy unwanted drinks, chips, etc...
Walked out the last time as they wouldn't take my card and I only had a five spot on me.  Lost business and not excited about going back anytime soon.
author: Z. G.

description: Delicious breakfast bagels and sandwiches in a cute environment. Super friendly staff. Take your breakfast next door to Farley's and enjoy it with a double shot of espresso. Hang out and enjoy the neighborhood vibe. What more could you ask for?
author: P F.

description:
Good freakin' gawd Amani, chill the hell out! Ok- one... I've been eating at Hazel's since around when they opened, 10+ years ago. It's one of the only places I've eaten at on a regular basis since opening, that I've never gotten food poisoning from. Just fwiw.

The one time they f*cked up and put dairy in my sandwich, the owner (Leslie) felt so bad- and asked that if it ever happened again, to just call, and that they'd run-up another sandwich to my house (she knows I'm a neighbor). Ever since, she's always made sure that whatever I order is totally dairy-free, and I've never mentioned my allergy since.

Anyway- the food is so homey, so flavorful, so delicious. The BLT with Avocado is amaaazing... the pre-made salads I always get when I'm going to have a long day in my studio in Oakland. When I go in first thing in the AM and they don't have what I always order already made, Juan will tell me to go get a coffee and come back in a few minutes (they know that's my routine anyway), and he always has just one little tub of my salad made-up by the time I go back.

The perfect neighborhood lunch-spot. Excellent service, and it's significantly cleaner and kept to higher standards, than most restaurants (and yes- I've worked at many). 

Oh yeah- and now, they accept credit cards!
author: Nina A.

description:
My coworkers and I go to Hazels pretty often because it's quick and tasty. We usually take it to go, but for people looking for seating there is outdoor seating and they have an agreement with the coffee shop next door, so you can eat in there too. 

My favorites are the hot steak sandwich and the cajun sausage sandwich (when they have it as a special). The balsamic onions are delicious and the bread is super fresh. They also have good side salads like the beet and goat cheese salad with oranges. 

Whoever calls this place pricey is tripppin'...last time I checked $7-8 is pretty standard for a sandwich....especially in the potrero hill neighborhood. Plus- the $4.95 belgian waffle with egg, avocado and bacon is a steal!
author: Kat L.

description:
Their sandwiches are delicious, and BIG, like split between lunch and dinner big (ok, I don't have the biggest appetite). Soups are good too in my experience. They are friendly and it feels like a nice neighborhood shop.  
Three stars, because every time I've tried to get salads there (chicken salad, grain salad, potato salad, etc) they all have bell peppers in them, which I can't eat.  I know that I'm not the only one with serious bell pepper issues, because I meet people all the time who can't stomach them.  I understand putting them in salads, but if they're in every single one then people like me don't really have an option.  (I may be biased, but also think it's a lazy way to add some color to a salad and it seriously changes the flavor!)
That said, I still go whenever I'm feeling up for a sandwich.
author: Ms. N.

description: Teeny Tiny Sandwich Shop Makes Big Tasty Sandwiches. Bring Your Wallet & A Friend.
author: Jordan P.

description:
I like to think of myself as a sandwich connoisseur...I love sandwiches!!  I really enjoy hazels....They have very healthy (not mostly meat)  sandwiches.  They are made with care, so don't go in a hurry....and I love that every sandwich comes with cucumbers and Hazels "special sauce."  ..It is always nice to order a sandwich and then take it to Farley's next door.  They let  you eat your sandwich in there shop! ...that is a whole other review..(I heart Farley's)......
Also, she has beautiful quiches and salads to pair with your sandwiches....yummy.   I am a regular.  Hazel's is my favorite sandwich shop in Potrero Hill!
author: Michele K.

description: Pretty good food with a nice menu and a cute space, but the girl who works here is notably unfriendly.
author: Dr. X.

description:
I weep as I write. Hazel's is true love for me. 

Back in the day I used to live on the hill and Hazel's was my home away from home. There was a time where I wouldn't eat tuna-fish, unless it was made before my eyes - until I tried Hazels. Wheat bread, White Cheddar, cucumbers, red onion, lettuce and tomatoes. Something so simple that exhibits pure perfection. 

I make the pilgrimage back every visit to SF. Well worth the long line!
author: Deidre H.

description:
MMMMMM Hazel's!

Roast beef with horseradish! Bagels with smoked salmon! Almost like being home on the East Coast.....
author: Emme D.

description: Okay, so nobody is perfect and Hazel's had a snag with my last sandwich. But instead of just saying "sorry" when she found out about it, Leslie was nice enough to give me my next sandwich on the house. Everyone at Hazel's is awesome, and it's clear that they care about their customers. I'm really glad to have them in the neighborhood!
author: Mr. B.

description:
When I first started going to Farley's I'd frequently see red-white tray-totting patrons step in and grub on sandwiches and soups. As Farley's doesn't make these items, I investigated and found that Hazel's, just a couple doors down, serves up these goodlookin' sandwich sets. As there is no place to sit- Hazel's is essentially a small kitchen and counter- they apparently have an arrangement with Farley's. Farley's will sometimes have a basket of sandwiches, presumably from when Hazel's closes shop for the day. 

So I stopped by and ordered a sandwich. Granted, I ordered one of their tamer items, but I've produced superior turkey sandwiches in my kitchen. 

And when I inadvertently tipped over the top bun, I found that the sandwich maker had stuck in a leaf of lettuce that was rotten black. How the sandwich maker though friendly, either (1) didn't see this disgusting fossilized leaf of lettuce, or (2) saw it and thought it was okay, is a head scratcher. If you go, best take a peek under the lid.
author: dave y.

description:
Resume: Shake Shack in CDM, deli and shakes specialist
Recommendations: Hot pastrami on a dark rye with everything and you are half way to a perfect lunch time.  Stop at Farley's for the beverage or the wine shop up the block next to Chez Maman.  Warning to presumptious peeps: no one in any of these places will kiss your ass.  Its just plain old good food with candid service.  Kind of surprised to read the sour reviews as they have always been extremely pleasant and warm and even comp'd a meal of mine when they forgot to include the side I ordered and had to return 10 minutes later.  
Follow up: Now I need to check out Kleins... we'll see
Get'r done, eat here and smile like you mean it
author: Porfirio R.

description: This is a great cafe for a bagel sandwich for breakfast.  (And the bagel sandwiches are made with fried eggs, not microwaved.  They now also carry brownies from BAKED which is bonus.   Their lunches are yummy too... mac and cheese, fresh sandwiches, etc.  It's a good spot and I'm glad it's in the work neighborhood.
author: shannon a.

description:
This is probably my favorite stop in SF.  Everything here tastes amazing, the staff are very friendly (including the owner, who is often there making your food), and it's easy to stop over to Farley's for coffee while your food is being made.  I have never once left this place unsatisfied or unhappy.

Oh, and they give you tootsie rolls with every meal as if your mom packed your lunch for you.  ADORABLE!
author: Ehron M.

description: Ordered a Jon special turkey and bacon for 8.50 to go. Half a sandwich into it and 4 blocks away I realized that there was no bacon. Honest mistake but a spiteful 3 star deduction.
author: Lily T.

description: You really are ordering out of a kitchen. Hand made huge sandwiches. I recommend the #5 on the sandwich board. Avocado, Cucumber, Tomato, Sprouts & Jack. or the #2 Hot Pastrami & Swiss or the #8 BLT with Avocado. For real, you can't go wrong. all the ingredients are fresh and each hunk of sandwich is made with love.  Thank You Hazel's for making sandwiches hip and scrumptious!
author: Charlene K.

description: It's 4+ years since my previous review and the only thing I would change is that I need more stars. Hazel's still makes fantastic, oversized sandwiches. And now they've expanded the lunch menu to include quesadillas & tacos, plus waffles, pancakes & eggs for breakfast. The food is fresh, the people are friendly, and if you're really lucky, you get an official greeting outside Hazel's by my dog Otis. What are you waiting for?
author: P C.

description:
I just got the turkey sandwich special for the second day in a row. it's SO good. I also got the beet salad, which is possibly even better.

highly recommended.
author: John M.

description: Mmmm... I had a great chicken pesto sandwich, with everything, here for lunch today. There appears to be no seating inside but they have a deal with Farley's so you can take it in there. Will definitely try Troy E's tip next time and get a cookie.
author: Bob G.

description:
I really wish Hazel would either hire some decent help, or just stay closed on days that she isn't willing to work.  The incompetence of the staff falls into a special class that is almost admirable in its extreme:  They made a sandwich that was practically the exact opposite of what we ordered.

The girl at the counter may have been new, but it was as if sandwich concepts themselves were foreign to her, not just the menu.  "What are these things you call 'cheese' and 'bread'?"  We would have had better luck going through a fast-food drive-through without ordering and just paying for whatever the people behind us wanted.

Getting charged $6.95 for a giant roll ("sourdough that has been sliced" versus the requested "sliced sourdough") with no lettuce or tomato, mayonnaise, or mustard is not how I want to keep the economy afloat.  We got home, and had to basically make a sandwich out of the paltry ingredients by adding our own.  Glad we had all that stuff in the fridge.  

We are considering opening up a sandwich repair shop in the Dogpatch.
author: Justin F.

description:
True potrero insiders know that hazels NOT klein's is where you get the good sandwiches. the turkey with cranberry and the ham and cheese are awesome. do yourself a favor- get the dutch crunch. you'll thank me. shout out to the cookies as well. and it's adorable.

NOTE TO ANYONE WHO WENT THERE BEFORE THE LAST FEW MONTHS: there was a totally mean woman who worked there. she's gone. yee haw! new staff are friendly and fantastic. when my hubsand and i split a sandwich they put onions and cuc's on my half (he's the princess and the pea i swear!!!!). one woman always laughs and goes "oh yeah! i remember your husband!" so great.
author: sarah l.

description:
Dear Hazel's Kitchen,
   If it is 2:00pm on a Wednesday and a large group of people who are obviously hungover request a table...wouldn't getting them a table in due time be the smart thing to do?

Instead you made us stand outside, watching the ONE outdoor table you have get filled by a group of people that looked as if they had just returned from Burning Man. Which was odd, considering I ate here in APRIL. 

I mean, that's just cruel, Hazel's. How come they got food before us? I'm sure I looked a lot worse-for-wear than they did, because I am not a happy camper without a morning cup of coffee.

But you finally came through for us and you let us in. Our table was haphazardly thrown together and your waitress wouldn't even look us in the eye. Good thing she brought me my coffee promptly, though. She probably didn't have to make eye contact to see that I would kill her if she did not deliver.

The food arrived quickly enough and was hot. I ordered some kind of scramble, minus the eggs. My only complaint was that there were WAYYYYY too many chunks of potato in it.

Their menu is pretty diverse, all things considered. Lots of options for whatever stupid restrictions you might have, you fucking hippie.

Toward the end of our dining experience, I was pretty sure we were going to die because a mighty disturbing smell was wafting through the small establishment. It smelled like some kind of electrical fire. Apparently Hazel's is still there, though.

This place was okay. Don't bring a large group here and if you're dying for caffeine be smart (unlike me) and go to Farley's before enduring the wait at Hazel's.
author: Pamela D.

description:
Wow . . . apparently people either LOVE it or HATE Hazels ;-)  I am going to with I LOVE IT!   I usually get the Rare Roast Beef and i love the fact that it seems like it is my sister making a sandwich for me in the kitchen at home . . . not that my sister EVER made anything for me when i was home but that is a different set of therapy sessions.

Since I work close by this is the place I go to if I need something quick.  Plus they have a frequent eating card . . . sweet!
author: Bruce R.

description:
I had a fine scrambled egg bagel sammie this morning, though I was distressed to read (just now) in Tommy S.'s review that there are some unsanitary, non-handwashing habits going on.  Yuck.  One person made my egg sammie, and another took my money, so I didn't notice, but Tommy's review just seriously turned my stomach.  Bleh. Bleh.  Bleh.  

(The eggs were fine, the avocado fresh, so I was fine with the edible part of my experience, and I hope Tommy's wrong, or that they've changed their ways.  I thought another reviewer's point was fair, which was that you can make just the same at home, so it wasn't extraordinary.  But it was a solid three stars.  Assuming the handwashing issue is fixed.  Blech.  Yuck.  Kills me.  Big yuck.)
author: Laurel B.

description: I can't remember why I ended up on Potrero Hill last Saturday, but it was around lunch time and this seemed like a good place for a nosh.  The sandwich combination I ordered was delicious (including the bread) and the staff were not only competent, but friendly and present for my order.  The cafe space, although small, was nicely appointed and welcoming (inside and outside).  I look forward to coming back again.
author: Eric B.

description:
I really want to love Hazel's - it is an absolutely adorable little take-out/sandwich shop in my neighborhood. In addition to sandwiches, they offer a few hot  dishes (i.e mac and cheese) and salads. 

I have only gotten food from Hazel's twice, and both times they were out of the thing I wanted (bad luck or standard fare; I'm not sure). Yesterday I got a truly mediocre $9 "chef's salad," which was clearly just standard sandwich fixings in a to go box, topped with a super bland dressing that I had to doctor-up at home (insult to injury).

According to my husband, the sandwiches are good but a little scant in the meat department.
author: rachel m.

description:
I like the location and the retro-grandma design of the store and the graphic design. And, that you can bring your food to Farley's.

HOWEVER, it's always service with a snarl and the ladies behind the counter always seem displeased to see you. The sandwiches are made of cheap ingredients and remind me of something you'd get a the deli counter of a Safeway!

It's such a missed opportunity to go full-on and keep up with San Francisco's food quality AND keep the vintage vibe. I wish they made watercress sandwiches, yummy deviled eggs and good fresh bread and quality sandwiches. Instead, the food tastes like cardboard.  The mac and cheese? Awful. Salad? Yuck.

The stars are only for the cute look of the place. The designer deserves a 4-store for re-vamping a hole in the wall to such a cute spot. But  that's not reason enough to go there, esp since it's take out only and food is not good.
author: Lala B.

description:
These are sandwiches the way you wish your mom would've made them for you! A very homemade, California-fresh feel, with friendly service to boot.

There's no space to eat inside so plan to take out unless it's a sunny day  and the tables are open.
author: Mel C.

description:
The best sandwiches in the city.  The secret...fresh, quality ingredients piled atop very good breads.  Simple yet effective.

Oh yes, the service is ALWAYS friendly and welcoming.  

Line can be a little long at lunch time but you'll typically have your sandwich in 2-10 minutes.
author: Brent R.

description: A sandwich shop with sprouts!  Now that's a great sandwich shop in my book!  My coworker ran and got sandwiches from this place for lunch recently and wow was I happy she did!  Since everyone on the menu sounded so tasty we decided to share a couple different sandwiches.  We had the #1b Roast Turkey & Swiss with Pesto on Dutch Crunch and the # 5 Avocado, Cucumber, Tomato, Sprouts & Jack on Whole Wheat.  Both were amazing! And very filling!  I didn't even have to move on to the tasty chips they also offer.  But actually who needs the sides when the sandwiches are this good!  Can I just say "have you checked out the menu!"  All of the signature sandwiches sound great, they offer all of my favorite bread choices, they have sprouts!, compostable wrappers and recyclable containers and great combinations!  Five Stars for sure!
author: Jennifer B.

description: Yum! Always excited to see veggie chili on a menu, and thrilled when it is tasty! The double fudge brownie was amazing when resurrected from the bottom of the purse later.
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
Licking cranberry off my fingers while typing probably isn't the best time to write a review...

BUT, I just couldn't wait to give Hazel her 5 stars. I've been to Hazel's Kitchen quite a few times before, here in Potrero, and am now asking myself how I manage to drive by so often without stopping. Well, lets just say I'll be pulling over more frequently.

I'm done licking my fingers and just finished the Roast Turkey & Smoked Provolone with Cranberries sandwich. Hazel (aka Leslie?) is not skimpy when it comes to making a sandwich. Even on sliced bread, the sandwich was huge, scrumptious and so fresh. Really, it's just amazing how she can make a somewhat ordinary sandwich taste so extraordinary.

The little kitchen has a great feel to it too. Light and airy. Great design too (thumbs up to the designer - I grabbed his card as I'm a graphic designer as well). Her young son rang me up and the little guy was quick and a whiz at math too! Great family feel to compliment the quaint environment up here on the hill.

Five stars, great sandwich, great service... Thanks!
author: Greg Ciro T.

description:
Shameful sandwiches.....

Five of us ordered food (sandwiches, chili, salads) to go from Hazel's.  The sandwiches had literally TWO slices of seemingly pre-packaged deli meat, one slice of cheese, and not much else.  I ate the first half because I was super hungry, and didn't eat the second half at all.  

Two of my co-workers who ordered sandwiches actually had blue marker ink on their BREAD.  Apparently the marker that the sandwich maker used to write the type of sandwich on the wrap is of super industry grade.....

Oh, and don't order the macaroni and cheese, because it costs close to $8, the portion is ridiculously small, and they conveniently forgot to put the salad (that's supposed to come with the macaroni and cheese) in the bag!!!

Unacceptable!!
author: Yelper F.

description:
The turkey sandwich, with cranberry sauce.  It is so delicous, it almost made me cry... twice.
  
Not only do they make a delicious sandwich, they sometimes throw fruit-flavored tootsie rolls into their to-go bags (no joking).   I'll never forget the day I finished a sandwich from Hazel's, then discovered a green apple tootsie roll in the bag under those folded-up napkins I forgot to use... amazing.

I hope Hazel's never leaves.
author: Greg G.

description:
Soooo goood! Super friendly, courteous and accommodating.
I highly recommend the hot steak sandwich on dutch crunch  and the caesar salad!

Super, super  cute neighborhood gem with high quality food.
author: mary s.

description:
I walked over there to order a sandwich to go. It was my first time and I think I got there at the right time (around 12:15) because after that, there was a big line.

I ordered the BLT with Avocado on Whole Wheat.....
YUM. I loved that the bacon was very thin and crisp. There were crunchy cucumbers and tomatoes in there along with a TON of Avocado. Usually there is just a slice or two in there but mine had a bunch.

DELICIOUS.....

What they also get extra kudos for is that they give you two tootsie rolls in your bag. Yeah!

I didn't give them 5 stars because I didn't eat it there nor did I try anything else. But I am most definitely going back there soon.
author: Christine S.

description:
After hearing from some buddies that the sandwiches as Hazel's Kitchen were really good, I recently had the opportunity to try a sandwich.  When I walked into Hazel's Kitchen, I liked the feel of the place with a household kitchen and friendly small business feel, the type of place I usually especially like giving my business to.  

As far as the food though, first off, a one star might be a little harsh but the rating is purely on the hot pastrami and swiss sandwich.  I ordered the pastrami and swiss sandwich and when the cashier said that my sandwich was ready, I looked at the sandwich and said, "I think this is the wrong sandwich."  The cashier clarified that this was the right sandwich.  Huge disappointment, my pastrami sandwich had so little meat I couldn't even tell if I got the right sandwich because it was covered with lettuces and other garnishes. When I think of a good hot pastrami sandwich, I think of a sandwich overflowing with meat and usually on rye bread.   

I have heard the other sandwiches are great from friends, but I was disappointed in the hot pastrami sandwich.  The pastrami was average tasting so if it had more meat it probably would have been worthy of about 3 stars.
author: Josh K.

description:
i don't usually spend money on sandwiches unless they're worth it, and i don't usually get chicken cuz i all about the beef, but just had the Chicken Chipotle on seeded roll and IT WAS AMMAAZZZZIINNNGGG!!!!

sandwiches are usually juicy but not soaking wet, and they're definitely thick.

get at it.
author: Pris C.

description:
Yummy turkey cranberry sandwich. 

Slow slow slow service. Like "makes me want to jump behind-the-counter and make the sandwich myself" slow.
author: Erin H.

description: Hazel's Kitchen is my favorite neighborhood eatery.  I have been eating at Hazel's nearly every day since I moved to the neighborhood, enjoying their sandwiches and breakfast burritos.  Recently Juan and Alma, the friendly chefs of the kitchen, have been creating some new tasty treats.  My recent fave for lunch are the tacos, and my new breakfast treat is the belgian waffle with fruit!  Mmmm!  Better than the food is the friendly service from Leslie, the talented and successful owner, and from Aimee, who remembers my order, and always offers a friendly smile.  Thanks guys!  This review is long overdue!!
author: erica s.

description:
Note: this is a review for breakfast at Hazel's - not lunch. I plan on returning for lunch to see if it's any better!

Being next to Farley's, I had high hopes for Hazel's. I was really disappointed with their breakfast selection. Completely uninspired "egg & bagel sandwich" was just exactly that. Literally an egg plopped on a bagel. So you gotta add tomatoes or sprouts or cream cheese, etc. Each additional topping costs more. Lame. Totally lame. The giant "WE HAVE BAGELS" sign out front led me to believe they had bagels. But, actually, what it should have said was, "WE HAVE BAGEL", as the only bagel choice that was left was a garlic bagel. Not a bad bagel, but still worth noting that they don't have much of a selection. My $5 bagel sandwich was good, but definitely not worth $5. 

I am looking forward to returning for lunch - hoping it'll be a better experience!
author: Jono K.

description: Been back several times since, and happy that the cash and food have since been separate each and everytime. Must've been  a new hire glich...back to lovin' you, Hazel's.
author: Elle N M.

description:
Good lord, I can't even begin to describe how awesome their chicken pesto sandwiches are. But don't you worry, because I'm going to try:

The sliced sourdough is moist and firm and with just the perfect hint of flavor-adding goodness that any bread should add. The wonderful assortment of tomatoes, lettuce, and cucumbers is superbly fresh and tasty and in just the right ratio to the focal point, which of course is the slices of chicken which are quite thick and juicy. And the pesto sauce--- oh, how I love their pesto sauce. I haven't tried this option yet, but you can add their wonderful pesto to ANY sandwich for just 50 cents more, so if you're not a chicken lover too, that'd be a good way to go.

Plus, everyone there is super friendly, and I don't understand why some people have said they are slow at making the sandwiches. Helllo, if there are 10 people waiting in front of you, that's 10 more sandwiches to make before yours! Just go chill outside for a while on this lovely section of 18th street. I promise it's more fun that hovering over the counter and freaking out for 10 minutes until your sandwich is ready.
author: Ryan L.

description: Delicious breakfast burritos, so good they melt in your mouth!
author: Kate V.

description: Hazel's is quite simply the best take-out sandwich joint in the City, and I've tried 'em all. The sammies are tasty and affordable, the place is clean, the service is warm and friendly, it's everything you need. Take your lunch next door and enjoy the ambiance at Farley's. It's a win-win.
author: TJ Z.

description:
Great food Great people. 

Very good neighboorhood deli.  Great for breakfast and lunch.  Food is well prepared with a very friendly staff.  Love the sandwiches.  Keep up the good work!
author: Larry W.

description:
I'll give it one star because they're still in business and two stars for location, location, location.

If you like your sandwiches drenched in runny mayo, wet lettuce and tomato, and aggressive red onion pilled high then this is the place for you. My biggest complaint would be the false advertisement on the 'rare roast beef'. The roast beef on my sandwich was about as rare as 1-day old road kill. I took a bite off a second sandwich (my wife's), grilled chicken something or other, and well the overlap to my sandwich was incredible. The taste of the chicken got lost in the mayo-lettuce-tomato-cucumber-red onion juice. Y U C K  I E S.

As a general rule, not being in the restaurant business, if there's too much sauce or gunk on food, then it simply isn't clean or high quality. If this sandwich was $5 no problem, but we're talking $8 plus... and so I've come to expect more. 

I was so insulted by their interpretation of 'rare roast beef' that I called the manager and I was told that next time I should ask "How rare is today's advertised rare roast beef"? This sounded a bit absurd, should I ask my Barista at Starbucks how much caffeine does my espresso have TODAY?

Prediction:  The popular breakfast burritos (which I haven't tried) will be loaded with some concoction of tomatoes, red onion, garlic, and vinegar which they will call pico de gallo... to again... hide the taste/quality of the real ingredients but to appeal to the unsophisticated palate. It's the same formula that 1001 Chinese food restaurants follow in metropolitan areas all over America... for instance.

I'm new to the area so I may go back for safe choices such as bagels and oatmeal. I challenge the crowds outside to expect more from your food. Don't sacrifice taste or quality for convenience... especially as there are up and coming establishments just a short bike ride away.
author: Ivan A.

description:
Change the name to Dirty Hand Hazel's with attitude!

I don't know why the girls that work here have such a bad attitude, if you don't want to help people and take orders then don't work in the service industry. Also, don't take orders then proceed to help make sandwiches without washing your disgusting mits. I just noticed this today and while it wasn't my particular order that was being violated with money filth, this is clearly unexceptable  and I have every right to call the health department and let then know about this unhealthy practice.

Also, I don't know how many times we've gone in and they tell us it will be 5 minutes and we'll end up waiting 15 or 20 minutes. One time we called ahead thinking we'd just walk right in and pick them up 10 minutes later. No chance. Even though we called ahead, we got there with no one else was waiting and they forgot to make our sandwiches and didn't even apologize for screwing up. I live in this area and I think it's important to support your local shops and eateries but, Hazel's can keep their bitchy attitude and poorly made sandwiches. I'd rather go to Togo's then deal with the constant screw-ups and crabby workers. At least I'll get chips and a drink for the same price and they wear gloves while making their sandwiches. What a concept!
author: Elizabeth B.

description: Hazels is just a very, very cute little breakfast & lunch spot.  It's got old-timey charm and good little breakfast burritos.  I really love the veggie sandwich (add sun dried tomato spread), but get it on toast, the bread kinda falls apart otherwise.  Veggies are wet.  :)  They couldn't be friendlier and the place couldn't be cuter.
author: Emily T.

description: Average.  Not awesome, not horrible.  Cute little local sandwich + shop in a quaint little neighborhood.  The meat seems processed and they have a funky(for my taste) secret sauce.  Friendly and fair.  Give a try, but the best sandwiches on Potrero Hill are at Chiotra's on Rhode Island, between 20th and 21st!!   Cheers..........
author: Jeff N.

description:
It's been years since I've gotten a sandwich from Hazel's, but the return visit had me asking why I waited so long?  I ordered a turkey with cranberry on dutch crunch and rather than finding a rotting piece of lettuce mentioned by another yelper, I tasted only the freshest ingredients.  My side of greek cucumber salad was equally fresh and delicious.

I guess I must've gotten lucky because my sis, who eats here more often, has mentioned the inconsistency of their sandwiches.  That seems to match other yelp reviews, but based on my most recent experience, I have to give Hazel's 4 stars.
author: Janut B.

description: Super small but super great too. I really enjoy the sandwiches here. They seem to have interesting specials too. It's not to fun if its raining and there's a bunch of people since the place only holds about 5 people but it is definitely worth it.
author: mark h.

description:
The guys at Hazel's Kitchen make a good sandwich. Fresh ingredients, fresh bread, and no irritating reminder "it's extra for avocado", like Whole Foods gives. 

We build our own: turkey with avocado, lettuce, tomato, red onion, pesto and light mayo, on toasted dutch crunch. It's addictive. Have it once and you'll find yourself thinking about it the next day around lunch time. You might just go back and get it again.

The minestrone was good, but don't eat the tiny meatball in it. It's a small hamburger lump.

This is a no frills shop with food to go. The outdoor tables are nice in the summer, but in the winter, get your food and then go next door for coffee. The coffee shop will let you eat Hazel's food at one of their tables as long as you patronize them as well.

This is 3 stars, not 4, because we've never tried the salads, which are the other half of their menu.
author: Simone E.

description:
Hazel's is cute as a button. I mean really cute. It's small. If it were a puppy, it would be a Maltese http://www.kateconnick.com/postcards/harleemalt0304.jpg or a chihuahua http://www.chihuahua.hu/kepek/tucsisztar.jpg Unfortunately this may explain Hazel's Napoleon complex - you'll understand in a moment.

Each time I visit Hazel's I stare agape in amazement as a three person crew deftly whisks about a kitchen the size of a postage stamp. Not only is it small as a thimble, but kitchy like a thimble. The whole shop is tastefully done up in pastel with 100s of knick-knacks and matching dishware. One wonders does food actually come from this play kitchen?

Indeed it does. And it's decent... tasting. I've had a garden salad with tuna. It was delicious - but totally weird. When taking my order to go I was like, "Damn! This salad's heavy!" Is this good value for my money, or just overcompensation for a pint-sized kitchen? The salad had nearly a whole mixing bowl of tuna on top. I mean, there was at least a pound of the stuff - a one inch tuna layer to dig through before you hit any greens. There was no way I could eat all that tuna. Did I mention that fisherman were out of work because the sea was now devoid of tuna?

Another occasion I ordered a roast beef sandwich and forgettable macaroni side salad. My friend and I shared at a cozy pastel table on the sidewalk. The sandwich was tasty but Hazel's hangup reared its ugly head again. The sandwhich was nearly 4 inches tall. Despite my best effort to unhinge my jaw I couldn't wrap my maw around it. I had to take a play from Napolean and divide and conquer my lunch.

Quarter point added for free Ritz crackers for kids and giants, like me, to nibble on while waiting for sandwiches.

(3.25 * stars)
author: Brady K.

description: Had a disappointing sandwich here today after hearing and reading positive reviews. Had the rare roast beef sandwich  which wasn't - brown is not rare. Whole wheat bread had the flavor and texture of brown Wonder Bread. Horseradish mayo had very little in it and the quality and the bread made the sandwich fall apart. Maybe I ordered the wrong thing but the experience reminds me why I don't generally like most deli style sandwhichs. Should have spent extra $$ for the awesome BLT or grilled cheese at Plow.
author: John B.

description: excellect menu, but not as good as the seem to rush orders. My tacos were pretty flavorless and soggy hot off the grill. A bit overpriced at $7.95. staff is super nice! ill give their sandwiches a try as that seems what they are known for. best to stick to mission if u want tacos :)
author: Sharif R.

description:
Cute sandwich shop in the Potrero Hill area...the food is decent for a quick bite, but the service is a little out of it (though they redeemed themselves, read on) and the food isn't something you can't find elsewhere (albeit, the ingredients are very fresh and seem like veggies from a great summer day, which you can't find everywhere but you can still find them at a grocery store and other small delis).

Came here today with a group of people, and my boyfriend had a roast beef/horseradish sandwich (very crisp and fresh veggies like tomato and cucumber, no soggy or shredded lettuce type fare, the horseradish was a good touch), and I had the mac and cheese (very cheesey, baked together like a mac and cheese casserole with a crumbly top, pretty good). However, the salads in the display case didn't look too fresh, I requested a fruit salad and only after I paid and my mac and cheese was ready did they tell me they didn't have any fruit salad (they mentioned they had ran out earlier, but just didn't think to tell me when I was ordering, thus, the 'out of it' ness I referred to earlier). 

However, the service was definitely nice and not snarling. The woman behind the counter smiled and said I could have a bagel instead of the non existent fruit salad. She also asked if I wanted any spread and if I wanted it toasted. That totally made up for the 'out of it' ness.
author: Katherine P.

description:
Went in here for lunch one day. Nice sandwich selection. I got the Veggie special sandwich. sooo yummy. My friends and I all loved our sandwiches. 

The only downside- mine took FOREVER to come. It's raw veggies on bread, it shouldn't take 15 minutes for it to come out, especially when there is no one else in line. My friends sandwich, with cooked meat in it, came out a full 10 minutes before mine. Maybe they were making sure the vegetables were extra fresh...
author: Ellen R.

description:
Okay, Hazel's Kitchen promotes its "Hazel's Bagels" prominently. But I asked the woman who works there about it, and she told me they don't make their own bagels! I mean, isn't that false advertising? She seemed really perplexed why I was bothered that they call them "Hazel's Bagels" even though they aren't homemade. I guess they put the sandwich fixin's on the bagels themselves, but somehow that still just doesn't ring true for me. 

Nevertheless, Hazel's Kitchen makes a fine sandwich. And their interior decor is really cute with its retro look. And they are conveniently located right next to Farley's, where you can eat your sandwich along with a big cup o' coffee.
author: Melinda K.

description:
The design is quite unique and the place looks like one of those rare san francisco finds. The food was okay. Certainly not the best I've ever had and I agree with the other person who commented that it's "service with a snarl". 

I had the roast beef special which was decent though I wouldn't consider it worth the high(er) price. The best part of the sandwich was the bread.
author: Adam P.

description:
I've wanted to try Hazel's for a while and finally did.

We ordered the beat salad, veggie Asian salad, and quiche. As a beet salad expert, I can tell you that this one is definitely delicious. The veggie salad and quiche, however, were a complete waste.

I watched the lovely women behind the counter making sandwiches while we were waiting for our food and wish I had ordered one. The rare roast beef with swiss cheese and horseradish mayo sounds divine.
author: Brad C.

description: The first couple of times I went to Hazel's, I liked it. There were quality ingredients in my sandwiches, they were well made and tasty and the staff was nice and helpful. I've come to realize that that's because the owner took my order. I wish she would hire some people with good customer service skills instead everyone's got a bad attitude and the sandwiches have really gone down hill. The last time I went the bread was stale and this time, the ingredients were meager (I could've eaten a plain baguette and been happier) and there was really nothing good about it. I won't be going back.
author: amy W.

description: The #8 BLT with Avocado is my favorite! There is always a line, but moves quickly! Well worth it. The sandwiches are well worth the $7.50 as they are loaded to the max. They are not skimpy with their meat selection. I also happen to enjoy the tootsie rolls that are found in the bag as well!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Hazel's Kitchen has wings...
Remember spending the night spitting blood and hatred at the world after loosing your first tooth, only to wake in stupid fascination with a dollar bill and instant belief in faries?  Makes the pliers worth another visit, right?  The owner of Hazel's forgot my add-on bacon, and gave me a  FREE sandwich the next time.  I stopped believing in that kind of service long ago.
author: Brad B.

description:
their homemade dressing totally makes the sandwich.  i have only tried their vegetarian and tofu sandwiches, but those two alone get a standing  ovation in my book!  

i love how they pile on the ingredients evenly.  you can wrap your mouth around the sandwich and bite down without lock jaw.  they put tlc in making them.
author: Sheri N.

description: Yum yum yum!! This little place has absolutely FANTASTIC sandwiches! It's really small inside with minimal outdoor seating but perfect for take out/to go. The line gets pretty long at lunch, but the staff works hard and efficiently to make the food in a timely manner. Highly recommend!
author: Stephanie J.

description: Yummy sandwiches, great soups/chilli, best part is that you can take it next door to Farley's which is one of the best coffee joints in town.
author: Rachel L.

description: Ok sandwiches, although I don't like them all.  The bread I had was stale and old, although that may be the exception.  The wait was long.  Other than that, an average sandwich shop.  The sub place in West Portal is much better, though.
author: Honey L.

description: Sandwiches like your grandma would make.  If she loved you very, very much.  Fresh, high-quality ingredients.  And the salads and specials are yum, too!  If you're feeling confident about your bootang, get the mac and cheeeeeeeeeeeese...
author: Rosie W.

description: Last time i went to hazels i was just getting sick and i was craving the usual - roast beef and cheddar and seeded roll. Instead i ordered the lunch box with 1/2 avacado sandwich, corn chowder soup, and bean salad. Why oh why did i order these things when sick!? Despite this, Hazels is known for consistently wonderful food, great value and those yummy little candies they always throw in the bag. Thanks!
author: Jessica W.

description: I had a very unpleasant experience here when I went for lunch and ordered the turkey and cranberry sandwich.  There was something that was neither turkey nor cranberry in there and I couldn't bring myself to finish the whole thing.  I'm pretty squeamish about food.  And I don't know where they get their cookies, but mine tasted like it was 3 weeks old.  I know cookies, and these were really bad.  I'm sure they taste fine when they are fresh but they really shouldn't sell old baked goods.  They should throw them out after a week or less.
author: Jin W.

description: Yummy yummy pesto sandwiches!  They even toss in a little piece of candy.
author: Becky P.

description: Hazel's simply rocks.  Ya'll fed me well for a year and a half of lunch breaks while I worked in Potrero Hill.  It's well worth the 20% grade walk up Missouri St for their three bean salad or yummy sandwhiches and friendly folks.  I hear it's named after the owner's best friend's grandmother or something, so I guess there is no Hazel hanging out in the back, but whoever she is, keep on, keeping on.
author: Ben V.

description: I can't say I generally enjoy this place. My co-workers seem to love it, but every time I go my sandwich is beyond sub-par. My biggest complaint was the thickness of the pastrami. It was literally like trying to chew through leather. Maybe they're veggie sandwiches are alright, but I'll more than likely refrain from coming back again.
author: Bradley D.

description:
UPDATE: this *was* a 4-star review. Until I went in today to get a sandwich and the woman (with long, loose hair) was handed a taste of something being made by a co-worker and then LICKED HER FINGERS while she was making my sandwich! I WAS MORTIFIED!
I told the countergirl that she might want to suggest that the owner (?) NOT LICK HER FINGERS while making food!
When The Licker handed me my sandwich, she said, 'what's wrong?', to which I replied, "I'd prefer it if you didn't lick your fingers while you were making my sandwich. I'm going to eat it because I'm starving." (which I realized later wasn't a good idea, I pulled the sandwich apart and ate the half that she didn't touch post-lick, which was only the lettuce). I ended up only eating the meat, cheese and half the bread, discarding the potentially tainted veggies. YUCK! I was too hungry to think straight, or I'd have demanded a remake by a hygienic person.
Even if the maker had not LICKED HER FINGERS while making my sandwich, it was lame today. The bread was tough, the tomatoes color/flavorless. boo. I won't be rushing back to Hazel's any time soon. Too bad, since I've had four or so great lunches there in as many weeks. I'm pretty sure I can find a sandwich joint whose cooks don't LICK THEIR FINGERS as they go. 

OH! And the best part?? She held up her non-licky fingers, and said, 'I didn't touch your food, I used these fingers.' AS IF THAT MAKES IT BETTER! I am horrified. Don't go to Hazel's, at least not until they train their sandwich makers to NOT LICK THEIR FINGERS (and aren't they supposed to be wearing gloves, anyway?)!!!

Hazel's introduced me to the gorgeousness that is dutch crunch bread. OH MY GOD, what wonder! Have I lived under a rock all this time? Maybe so.
A turkey sandwich with cranberry sauce and provolone, on this magic bread. Perfect.
I had some black bean soup too, it was delish but too salty.
author: Amani Ellen L.

description: How come my sandwiches never taste as good as the ones I buy out?  My friend and I split a tasty tuna salad 'wich from Hazel's, and we fought over the crumbs.  Delicious.  Well-priced, too, at $6ish.
author: Jennifer O.

description: 5 Star Sandwiches! I LOVE their tuna. The portions are very generous and the owner is lovely. A real neighborhood gem! They catered a small meeting for me, and it went off without a hitch! Oh, and it's on sunny Portrero hill. Amazing!
author: jody l.

description: Yes yes yes.  This place is really worth the five stars (and I don't write many of these five star reviews).  I am completely addicted to their vegetarian sandwich (#5).  Fresh vegetables, avocado, cheese all HEAPED on top of fresh homemade bread, slathered with mayo.  There are not many times one would think of a veggie sandwich being hangover food, but honey, this sandwich has killed my hangovers for years.  And the owner of the place is the most precious jewel of them all.
author: Sarah F.

description: mmmm turkey sandwich with cranberry sauce, best sandwich ever.  CUTE is the word to describe this place.
author: Debbie Y.

description: Agreed, the sandwich is a good one.  I'll go back for the turkey + cranberry sandwich any day.  But the cookie -- I don't get it.  Best cookie in town?  Hummmm....I didn't experience the euphoria others have.  Mediocre at best.
author: Rufus X.

description: Hazel's is a great local joint that has much more than delicious sandwiches. They have daily specials of quiche, tacos, lasagna, unique salads, baked mac and cheese, and more. I love the fact they put cucumbers on all their sandwiches and serve them toasty by request.
author: Mike A.

description: Dee-lish. I decided to try out the sandwich shop by taking a friend there for lunch. I had the BLT w/A and he had the Roast Beef. I know my sandwich was delicious but I think my friend said it best. Midway through his 2-3rd bite he said, "Wow," (chew, chew chew) "Oh my God, this is sooo good." 'Nuff said?
author: Jeff G.

description: A weekend staple when I can get it. A coffee from Farley's, a bacon breakfast burrito, good company, and people watching. Its just a tortilla with cheese, egg, meat, and salsa, but its oh so good...or maybe its oh so convenient....either way it warms my belly. Remember to pour on the Tabasco!
author: Stacy T.

description: My, what large nipples you have Sir. Normally, I might not have noticed, but since we ordered nearly 20 minutes ago, there are only so many places for my eyes to wander as I wait out here on the sidewalk, and you stand there so awkwardly in that oddly sheer shirt. Geez, Hazel hurry up! I spent $8.50 to be disappointed by your small, severely overdressed Chicken Caesar salad.
author: J F.

description: I've never met Hazel but she sure has a legacy of awesomeness to live up to. The lovely ladies at Hazel's make the best sandwiches and are always super friendly.  Mornings bring bagels with as many veggie fixings as you could want, all for like $2. Cheapest loaded bagel eats on the Hill. They also do a brisk business during lunch, so you will often find a line 5 or 7 people deep around high time. Well worth the short wait and a good way to meet your neighbors. Take your order next door to Farley's and munch it down with some coffee while perusing a magazine from the rack. It's ok and encouraged!
author: Eddie C.

description: This is a great place in a quiet nieghborhood to grab lunch. Right next to Farleys. Sandwiches are hearty, salads, fresh, and the ladies that work there, very sweet.
author: Angela C.

description: worth the wait...sandwiches made just for you, so many choices..daily salads and soups wonderful. Today my children had the kids quesadilla (4.95)...don't go if you are in a rush...nice to enjoy outside across the street in the sun! So delicious!
author: Nancy H.

description: I heard great reviews about this place and well since I was in the neighborhood, we stopped by here to get lunch. Very nice, cute little sandwich shop. They also serve homemade pasta and burritos. I ordered the turkey, swiss,pesto on wheat and she had the chicken quesadilla. I think I should have chose the pesto lasagna. But it was very good. Long line out the door though and some outdoor seating if your lucky enough to grab one.
author: Mauling W.

description:
I do my laundry across the street, so I thought I would check out Hazel's while I was waiting.  I had the turkey and cranberry (it was before Thanksgiving and I was craving it.)  I thought it was delicious!  It was full of veggies and I didn't think there was too little meat, and the bread was soft and fresh (I had wheat.)  Next time I would get it without their sauce or light on the sauce because there was way too much.   The staff (two younger girls) were very friendly and fast, and it is decorated so cute!  I just wish they had fountain pop.  Next time I will definitely try the mac and cheese!
Update:  tried the mac and cheese.  Disappointing.  It would have been delicious if it was fresh out of the oven, but it was microwaved.   What can you expect given the size of the location and who they are catering to, it's not a sit down place.  Definitely edible and you even get a salad to go with it (though why is it every time I go in the options are coleslaw, 3 bean salad, or fruit, come on get some variety!) but probably won't order it again.
author: Sarah M.

description: Meh, 'split pea soup' more like bland green water with slices of deli ham tossed in carelessly. They're super nice, but man, do they need to step up the soup, especially now...soup season.
author: Colleen B.

description: Okay. This is tough. I love the sandwiches here. Really I do. But I walked up to the counter and the lady behind the counter left to check out her friends new cool track bike and was gone for about ten minutes. I mean really people? Its like you haven't seen a track bike before? You have a customer, that is ready to order. You put them on hold for a frickin look at a bicycle. Sigh... i was late getting back to work and I blame this lame hipster. Get a job at a bike shop. Back to the sandwiches! They are great! Avoid hipster bike obsessed girl and you will have a wonderful meal!
author: Jeff R.

description: Hazel's Kitchen is one of the best sandwich joints in the whole city. Even though they really have only one veggie (the number #5 on sliced sourdough, ahem) it is quite excellent; the avocados are always fresh and the tomatos nice and juicy. However, don't forget to buy a cookie. They sell one of *the* best cookies in all of SF made by 'The Cookie Freak', which I'm to understand is a sole woman in her kitchen. The cookies alone are worth your trip! I think the homemade ones at Hennessy's on 2nd are the only cookie competition.
author: Troy E.

description: Hazel's homemade sandwiches epitomize California -- always fresh and healthy, yet simple.  They even sometimes have creative-sounding tofu sandwiches that I as a carnivore have even contemplated trying.  I come to this cute mom-and-pop shop in my 'hood on a weekly basis.
author: Chris P.

description: This is a true neighborhood spot with delicious food.  Hazel's is so inviting (maybe because they know their customers by name), but as soon you walk inyou knowyou'll be taken care of.  I love it!
author: Danielle W.

description: Hazel's is a cute little hole-in-the-wall where the food is prepared right in front of you.  I often stop at Hazel's for breakfast and Farley's for coffee while I'm doing laundry on a weekend morning.  A breakfast bagel with egg and avocado is a great way to take the edge off a couple hours at the laundromat...
author: Lindsay G.

description: Beautiful brunette working the register. Beautiful blonde making the sandwiches. Ridiculously cute establishment on the whole. Didn't care that they were out of eggs (it was 3 in the afternoon, after all). Delicious sandwiches. Sentence fragments to represent hungover state of trip there. Four stars.
author: Pete J.

description: The people who work there and the food is AMAZING! They were so generous with providing food for a fundraiser that I was helping to put together. Everyone who had sandwiches was raving about them. You must try the Roast Turkey & Smoked Provolone with Cranberries and the Rare Roast Beef & Swiss with Horseradish Mayo. They are both so good, I'm getting hungry just thinking about them! Not only are they delish, but they are HUGH! A great buy for your buck.
author: sarah r.

description: Now that Klein's gone, what choice do I have for a sandwich under 4 blocks away?  Hazel's!  I used to love the place for a breakfast bagel on the weekends, but now I also get their yummy BLT with avocado.  The bacon is fully cooked and crispy, and there is plenty of avocado.  Yummy!  Not the cheapest sandwiches, but they're comparably priced to my work cafeteria and higher quality so I'm not complaining!
author: Amy L.

description: I went back recently, and they changed the mac 'n cheese.  It's OK, but not nearly what it used to be.
author: Lesley G.

description: I love this place for it's awesome breakfast burritos. Reasonably priced, friendly staff, decorated in a homey and comforting style. You can't go wrong with a sandwich from Hazel's!
author: Francisca J.

description: The other day I had  at Hazels the best BLT sandwichEVER!!!!!!! totally recommend this place, also their classic turkey provolone cranberry is delicious  and the salads mmmmmm..... and the people who work there are very very nice!!
author: Yvette F.

description: Favorite work lunch spot. They have cards that you get punched, and after ten punches you get a free sandwich. So after  going to get lunch for everyone I get a free sandwich out of the deal.
author: Pam J.

description: The #5 (veggie: avacado, sprouts, cucumbers, other veggies) is my favorite. This is not a place to visit when you're in a rush, cause they lovingly take their time to make each sandwich.
author: viv k.

description: I ate at Hazel's for the first time today...you wouldn't think that a sandwich could taste so darn good, but this was seriously delicious food. Forget about the sides and chips, the sandwich was huge. My partner had the turkey and cranberry with provolone cheese and I had the roast beef with horseradish mayo and thick slices of swiss. Cucumber slices, fresh tomato and onions added some crunch and the bread was soft and perfect. My belly is so happy right now. The prices were totally appropriate for the food. Hazel's is my new most favorite sandwich place in San Francisco. No seating inside...a few tables outside...seems like a take away place only. Worth the trip to Potrero.
author: Richard F.

description: This place is adorable!  Sit on their munchkin sized chairs while you wait and you can be adorable too!  Their sandwiches aren't bad either.  They remind me of the kind of sandwiches my high school cafeteria used to make which were by the way, so good that I still came back to have one of their sandwiches well after I graduated.
author: Jean A.

description: Great chef's salad.  Well rounded proportions, your choice of ingredients.  Be sure they get your order correct because I happen to know one loyal yet lately disgruntled customer.  Ritz crackers and candies to snack on while you wait.  I am enjoying an oatmeal chocolate chip cookie as I write this favorable review.
author: Melissa B.

description: I do laundry across the street and always notice a line coming out of Hazel's Kitchen.  I was starving and decided to try it out.  But I waited to see if the line would dissipate.  It didn't.  I braved waiting in the cold.  I know it's sunny Potrero Hill but it's been freezing for the last two weeks and Hazel's Kitchen was on the shady side of the street.  I ordered the vege sandwich and asked for cucumbers and a small vege chili.  Hazel's Kitchen's interior looked like something I would find in a Martha Stewart magazine.  It was nice and clean.  I thought the sandwich was a tad too expensive(total $10) for what it was(not loaded enough) and the chili was just okay.  Oh and they forgot my cucumbers.  Boo.
author: Joni S.

description:
Good sandwich, albeit too thick. But I really liked the quality of the ingredients that went into making the sandwich. That day, I had the carrot-ginger soup and their oatmeal-chocolate chip cookie. Both were excellent.

I still need to go back one day to fully investigated their menu and assign a rating. For now, 3*.
author: Rahul T.

description:
A great place to grab a quick bite to eat. I'm a big fan of their lunchbox special which includes a half sandwich (I'm partial to the roast beef with horseradish mayo), a small soup and a side salad. And when I say it's a great place for a quick bite to eat, I mean it. You are in and out within three minutes. 

The only reason they lack the fifth star in my review is the lack of seating.
author: Scott W.

description: I just moved to Potrero and have eaten at Hazel's a few times now...for breakfast and lunch. I like their sandwiches and the girls have always been nice to me. I think if you are pleasant you typically get a pleasant response back.  And for goodness sake, it's a sandwich shop not Gary Danko.   I love their bagels with scrambled eggs for breakfast!  Hits the spot with a coffee from Farley's.
author: Kelly M.

description: This place is solid. They don't skimp on their fillings.  You can expect half an avocado - not just a smear - plus cucumber, lettuce, sprouts, and tomato.  Minus one point for the wimpy store-bought bread.  At 8$ a sandwich I expect a thick cut of something fresh baked.
author: Fallon C.

description: I was at the amazing Collage Gallery next door and was super hungry so decided to forgo sweets at the great Farley's two doors down and try Hazel's. My first impression was "How effing cute!" I loved the 50's decor and interior. I loved the story of the shop even more and I was smitten by the pics of the owner's twins. I'm a single mom and small biz owner so it touched me. I wanted to support it. I wanted to come back again and again. I ordered a piece of pre-made veggie quiche and somehow I waited a very long while for it to come out of the microwave scalding hot. I saw other folks being served rather quickly and their stuff was more complex. I was patient though I wanted to go back there and help. The server and the register person WERE very nice and I luckily had no finger licking experiences. I do have to say though, yes, they are supposed to have their hair back and yes, they are supposed to wear gloves which they were not doing. That may be a health code problem and that sucks but I'm not freaking out about it. The quiche was lovely and it was a good size too. I'll probably go back but yeah, it took too long and was too hot and I had to wait 7 or so minutes after I got it for it not to burn my mouth.
author: Melisa B.

description: I am a sucker for daily specials. I usually like to try them whenever I can. Today the sandwich specials at Hazel's Kitchen had me locked in a state of indecision for about 5 minutes. When it came time to order, in usual fashion I made a last minute decision and picked a winner. A turkey sandwich between two slices of whole wheat with a pesto aioli, warm provolone, and lots of veggies - lettuce, thinly sliced zucchini, caramelized onions, and roasted red peppers - tossed in a light balsamic vinaigrette. The beautiful colors made it even more appetizing. Mmm, mmm, good! My only complaint (yes, I know that I'm a snob) is that the turkey cold cuts were too salty for my taste, and the texture of the cut resembled the ones that come in a 100 slice bulk pack. I would've much preferred an oven roasted breast. It would be just as good without the meat. But yes, aside from that, it was delicious with a capital D. Extra points for the cuteness of the interior!
author: Monica N.

description: Used to be a huge fan of Hazel's until today, when I pulled three hairs out of the inside of my sandwich...
author: amanda r.

description: Decided to grab breakfast at Hazels when I was getting my coffee at Farley's next door. I got a bagel with their lox spread which was pretty good. They actually use real lox in the spread versus the over processed stuff you find at most places. You could tell because the spread was  white with pink spots, not all pink. My boyfriend got the scrambled egg sandwich. I had a bite and it was terribly bland even though I watched them season it. They make the eggs in the microwave which never fares well. They were rubbery and dry. Yuck. The service here was pretty bad. Super slow! And before you ask -- no there were not a bunch of people in front of me. I had time to go to Farley, order 2 lattes, and finish my whole latte in the time it took them to make my order. It took about 15 minutes for us to get our orders and neither were difficult to make especially considering the eggs were microwaved. I MIGHT go back to try their sandwiches but it is doubtful. I'll just stick to Farley's and their yummy pastries.
author: Sierra d.
